issues.description: The problem statement text (Part 3, Play the Song) instructs students to implement the helper method singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal) as public for easier testing, but the UML diagram in the same problem statement marks singFarmSongVerse as private. Both the provided template and the reference solution implement singFarmSongVerse as private. This is an internal contradiction in the problem statement and a cross-artifact visibility mismatch: students are told to make the helper public but the starter code and solution use private. This can confuse students (and automated tests) about the expected visibility of the helper method.
issues.suggested_fix: Resolve the contradiction by choosing one visibility and applying it consistently. If tests expect direct access to the helper, change the template and solution method to public: public void singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal) { ... }. Otherwise, update the problem statement text to remove the instruction to make the helper public (or state explicitly that the helper is private and will not be directly tested). Prefer changing the template to public only if automated tests rely on calling the helper directly; otherwise prefer aligning the problem text with the UML (private).

issues.description: The template declares the helper method as singFarmSongVerse(/*Animal animal*/) with the parameter commented out (i.e., currently a no-parameter method), while the problem description (and the reference solution) expect a singFarmSongVerse method that accepts an Animal parameter. This mismatch in parameter signature between the template and the expected design will force students to change the method signature (and could cause confusion or compilation issues if tests expect the parameterized version).
issues.suggested_fix: Update the template method signature to match the intended design: declare the helper with an Animal parameter (and visibility consistent with the chosen policy). For example: public void singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal) { ... } (or private if you align with the UML). Ensure the parameter is present in the template so students implement against the correct signature and so tests can call it if required.
